column1: Match the tissues on the left to the cells that form them:
column8:
Correct: A. Dentin ⇒ Odontoblasts
Dentin is produced by odontoblasts, which line the pulp cavity.

column1: The basic structural unit of the myofibril is:
column8:
Correct: C. Sarcomere
The sarcomere (Z-disc to Z-disc) is the functional and structural unit of a myofibril.

column1: Which is an example of a communicating junction?
column8:
Correct: D. Gap junction
Communicating junctions are gap junctions, allowing direct ion and small molecule transfer between cells.

column1: Secretory vesicles are formed by detachment from:
column8:
Correct: D. Trans Golgi network
The trans Golgi network sorts and packages proteins into secretory vesicles.

column1: The transitional epithelium is found at:
column8:
Correct: B
Transitional epithelium (urothelium) lines the urinary tract, allowing distension.

column1: The extramural glands are:
column2: Glands embedded within the organ wall
column4: Glands that secrete their products outside the walls of the organ
column8:
Correct: C
Extramural glands are located outside the organ wall and deliver secretion via ducts (e.g., major salivary glands).

column1: Monozygous twins may have:
column8:
Correct: C
Depending on timing of division, monozygotic twins may share amnion, chorion, and placenta.

column1: Mitochondria are:
column2: Organelles with cristae on their outer membrane
column4: Double-membrane organelles with inner membrane forming cristae
column8:
Correct: C
Mitochondria are double-membrane organelles; the inner membrane forms cristae and contains the respiratory chain.

column1: Which of the following answers is TRUE? Dystrophin in skeletal muscle cells binds:
column8:
Correct: C
Dystrophin links actin filaments to the plasmalemma, stabilizing muscle fibers.

column1: Which of the following answers is TRUE? The viscous external surface cover of the plasmalemma is called:
column8:
Correct: B. Glycocalyx
The glycocalyx is a carbohydrate-rich cell coat on the external surface of the plasma membrane.

column1: What is the main function of the microtubules:
column8:
Correct: C. Intracellular transport
Microtubules serve as tracks for motor proteins (kinesin, dynein) enabling vesicle and organelle transport.

column1: The active chromatin is:
column8:
Correct: B. Euchromatin
Euchromatin is lightly stained, transcriptionally active chromatin.

column1: Which of the listed cells does NOT belong to the glial lineage?
column8:
Correct: E. Martinotti cell
Martinotti cells are neurons of the cerebral cortex, not glial cells.

column1: The Ruffini´s corpuscles respond to:
column8:
Correct: C. Vibration and pressure
Ruffini corpuscles are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors sensing sustained pressure and low-frequency vibration.

column1: Which of the following properties is characteristic of rhabdomyocytes?
column8:
Correct: E
Skeletal muscle fibers exhibit excitability, conductivity, contractility, and limited regeneration.

column1: Which functional types of neurons innervate the neuromuscular spindles?
column8:
Correct: C. Sensory and motor
Neuromuscular spindles are innervated by sensory afferents and motor (gamma) efferents.

column1: The length of the molecule of the hyaluronic acid is approximately:
column8:
Correct: C. 2.5 µm
Hyaluronic acid is a very long GAG molecule, reaching approximately 2.5 micrometers.

column1: What is the shape of the nucleus of the monocyte?
column8:
Correct: D. Kidney-shaped
Monocytes have a characteristic kidney-shaped or horseshoe-shaped nucleus.

column1: Which of the listed cell contacts are found in the epithelial tissue?
column8:
Correct: E. All answers are true
Epithelia contain tight junctions, adherens junctions, desmosomes, gap junctions, and hemidesmosomes.

column1: Which of the following is a glia cell?
column8:
Correct: C. Ependymal cell
Ependymal cells are glial cells lining the ventricles and central canal of the spinal cord.
